perturbation.original_text: h.    "Enterprise" means any legal entity and the subsidiaries it owns by more       than 50 percent. The term "Enterprise" applies only to the portion of the       Enterprise physically located within the United States of America.
perturbation.changed_text: h.    "Enterprise" means any collection of individuals, regardless of legal structure or ownership. The term "Enterprise" applies to the portion of the collection wherever located.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition ties 'Enterprise' to a legal entity with subsidiary ownership, limiting its scope to the United States. The modified definition broadens 'Enterprise' to any collection of individuals, removing the legal entity requirement and geographic limitation. This conflicts with standard legal definitions of a business enterprise, potentially impacting liability and contract enforcement by making the scope of the entity unclear.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding the definition of legal entities and their subsidiaries.

perturbation.original_text: a.    it will perform the Services using reasonable care and skill and in       accordance with the applicable Service Option Attachments (which means the       degree of knowledge, skill and judgment customarily exercised by members       of the applicable profession with respect to work of a similar nature);       and that it will provide Customer with competent, fully trained, fully       qualified and responsible personnel to perform the Services;
perturbation.changed_text: a.    it will attempt to perform the Services as it sees fit. it will make an effort to provide Customer with personnel to perform the Services; and
perturbation.explanation: The original clause defines 'reasonable care and skill' using an industry standard and requires 'competent, fully trained, fully qualified' personnel. The modified clause removes the industry standard and replaces it with subjective assessment, and weakens the personnel requirement. This contradicts the implied warranty of workmanlike performance found in service contracts, creating uncertainty about the required level of service.

perturbation.original_text: Risk of loss for all Base Components shall at all times remain with IBM. Risk of loss for all Customer Components shall at all times remain with Customer.
perturbation.changed_text: Risk of loss will be shared between IBM and the Customer. The amount of shared risk will be agreed upon each month, depending on performance of the service.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause clearly allocates the risk of loss for 'Base Components' and 'Customer Components'. The modified clause replaces it with a vague concept of shared risk 'agreed upon each month', creating uncertainty and contradicting basic principles of contract law concerning risk allocation. This ambiguity could render the provision unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) principles regarding risk of loss.
